title: 113_hr4756
content: The Act is titled the "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act." It amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying, mandating local educational agencies to report bullying incidents within 7 business days. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying incidents based on protected characteristics, with exceptions for cases where students request non-reporting. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying incidents based on protected characteristics. A local educational agency must designate an individual to receive reports of bullying and inform all employees of the contact information. Within 60 days of receiving a report, the designated individual must inform all employees of the agency. The "BRAVE Act" requires a local educational agency to inform all employees of reported bullying incidents and publish quarterly reports summarizing the incidents for students and parents. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to publish quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and employee responses, excluding student identifiable information, and informing the public of the right to file complaints. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to publish quarterly reports on bullying incidents and employee responses, excluding personally identifiable information. Additionally, agencies must annually review bullying policies for schools and certify compliance with the Act to receive federal funding. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to certify compliance with quarterly reports on bullying incidents and establish a procedure for complaints to be submitted to the Office of Civil Rights. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to establish a procedure for complaints related to non-compliance with bullying incident reporting, which will be investigated by the Assistant Secretary. The "BRAVE Act" mandates local educational agencies to address non-compliance with bullying incident reporting. Failure to comply may result in withholding funds, issuing a complaint, or entering into a compliance agreement. The "BRAVE Act" requires local educational agencies to address non-compliance with bullying incident reporting by taking actions authorized under the General Education Provisions Act. The Assistant Secretary must make information about complaints available on the Department of Education's website within 60 days. The "BRAVE Act" mandates reporting bullying incidents, specifying characteristics involved and excluding student's personal information. Bullying is defined as severe, pervasive acts by one student or a group towards another on school premises. The "BRAVE Act" defines bullying as harmful behavior towards another student based on protected characteristics like race, color, sex, religion, disability, gender identity, and sexual orientation, causing harm or concern for the victim's well-being or withdrawal from school activities.
